Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: The carpenter is building custom cabinetry and needs to collaborate with other construction professionals to complete the project on time
Story: I glanced at the calendar, my granddaughter’s careful handwriting circling today’s date with a heart. The family gathering was something I’d promised not to miss—my daughter had even called last night, reminding me how much the little ones looked forward to baking cookies with Grandma. But as I set down the phone, my work boots caught my eye by the door. The cabinetry project at the new house was behind schedule, and the contractor had just texted, asking if I could meet the team this afternoon to finalize the framework. They were counting on me; the timeline was tight, and any delay would set everyone back. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the laughter and flour-dusted hugs waiting at home, and toward the half-finished cabinets and the trust my crew placed in my hands. I could almost hear my granddaughter’s giggle, but I could also picture the anxious faces of my colleagues. I stood in the hallway, keys in one hand, rolling pin in the other, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which door I would walk through.
